physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. The words “Poetry (monroe)” are written at the top, along with the date. The subsequent page has, typed, “H.M.-” followed by the page number. They also have the date.

div.p: Your letter is a surprise and a pain to me, for I did not suppose that you used your editorials as a means of boosting anybody. I thought, of course, that they were intended to be serious critical judgments, and that when you opposed English and American poets, one to the other, you were doing so in good faith, giving what you considered the best work in each country. Now you say that the article was “casual”, and that those “less conspicuous” than I need it more. If your editorials are propaganda, not criticism, they are mere newspaper work and unworthy of the position you wish to occupy as a serious critic and judge of poetry. This I am sure you will see yourself, and will agree with me that no editor has a right to take refuge behind “casual” work. It is like being casual in measuring out medicine; the results which follow are too serious. What would be forgivable, if hardly justifiable, in an ordinary writer, becomes of monumental importance in an editor of such prominence as yourself.

I am very glad that you are printing Fletcher's article on me in the June number, and, as you say, that stresses my work enough to satisfy any poet, but that was hardly my contention in my letter. I was not contending for recognition by other people, but by you. It was your words which I thought I had a right to receive and your pronouncements which I regretted your withholding from me.

If you look back over your editorials during the five years of “Poetry”, I think that you will notice that except where you have directly reviewed one of my books, you have carefully omitted mentioning me —
you yourself, I mean—and I think you will realize that in your position this is hard to bear. In one sense of course I do not “need” it, but what is a little newspaper talk and discussion. That is not what I am out for. I want the serious recognition of thinking people, and I want you to accord me the place which I have won for myself as well as to have others accord it to me. But we will not discuss that any more. Perhaps in the next editorial you write dealing with American literature as a whole you will find a niche for me. I hope so, at any rate, for it would grieve me more to think that you did not consider me worthy of such a place than that you merely did not express such an opinion.

Now I have two requests to make of you. May I review Eunice Tietjens's new book for you and also Louis Untermeyer's “These Times”? I consider Eunice's book one of the finest things I have read for ages, and, feeling so strongly as I do about it, I should like to express my admiration publicly. As to Louis's book, I find many things in it of very high grade, and I should very much like to write a review on it. These reviews can, of course, go in whenever you wish. In fact, I cannot promise to do the two of them under six weeks or so. I will do whichever one first that you prefer. Of course our original arrangement of my not being paid for prose holds good. Please let me do these reviews.

div.note: Lowell objects to being left out of Monroe’s editorial, “Colonialism Again," in Poetry Vol. 10, No. 2 (May 1917): 92-97. The editorial criticizes Yale University for awarding a poetry prize to the late British poet Rupert Brooke, pointing to it as an example of the American academy’s “timorous” attitude in recognizing the strength of American poets. Monroe lists Edgar Lee Masters, Vachel Lindsay, Ezra Pound, Carl Sandburg and H.D. as exemplary American poets. Monroe wrote to Lowell on May 21, 1917 that “it doesn’t seem necessary to mention you in a casual article—those less conspicuous need it more.” (May 21, 1917).
“Living History,” John Gould Fletcher’s review of Lowell's Men, Women, and Ghosts appeared in Poetry Vol. 10, No. 3 (June 1917): 149-153.

Eunice Tietjens, Profiles from China: Sketches in Verse of People and Things Seen in the Interior (Chicago: Ralph Fletcher Seymour, 1917); Louis Untermeyer, These Times (New York: Henry Holt & Co., 1917).
